SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

No. 6

Pioneer Farming Experiences.

(Drawing by Loren Teed)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Thomas William BENNETT

Present Address: Willow Ranch

Pioneer Address:

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1909

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 6

Pioneer Farming Experiences.

1. What led you to the particular district in which you settled?

My father wanted to join me here in Canada, and take up land so he contacted Mr. Vincent, who was in London City. Through whom was information about it obtained? Who recommended this district.

What was the extent of this information and what alternatives did you consider?

No other alternatives considered. This district just opening up for homesteading.

2. What was your previous experience in farming?

5 years mostly in Manitoba around Brandon Hills.

If none, under what circumstances did you learn?

3. Did you homestead? Yes.

If so, give description of the land (township, range, distance from the railway).

27-4-27 W2 80 miles from Railroad, Morse Jaw.

When, where, and how did you file your homestead entry?

In Act 1908. File in Walla Walla Bunch against Mr. P. LaPointe.

How much information did you have about the land when you filed your entry?

None. Just looked at over with a locator whom I had in Rouleau.

4. Did you obtain a pre-emption? Yes.

5. What other land did you purchase? NE 28-4-27 in 1944.

6. Was any of it Hudson Bay Company land, C.P.R. land, or school land? No.

What was the purchase price per acre? $20.00

What was the largest amount you possessed at one time? (Give date). 160 acres. NE 28-4-27. My father bought my father's land and added land making a total of 800 acres which I still own.

14. If you used oxen, how many did you have? 4

When and where did you obtain them?

1909 in Rockland

In regard to seeding and harvesting crops, the nearest elevator was at Moore Jaw till 1928-29 so we only grew a little wheat or flax but grew mostly oats for cattle feed.

Then the Railroad came to Vemwood and it increased our my cultivated land and it was only 22 miles to head.

Re water part. An Englishman and his wife named Murray settled here in 1910 - 1911. He had been a butcher in England but was useless as a farmer, only good to do what he was told. Didn't if he could drive a team. We became very well acquainted and friendly, one day he came to tell me his wife was pregnant. The nearest doctor was Regina 35-40 miles away. So I could be and his wife moved in with me. She didn't cost me would help me store to get ready for the clean breaking out. I would ride for the doctor when the time came. I agreed. I had a really good saddle horse horse. The day a rather might come in late April my neighbor Mr. Lauter a skilled midwife came up and I rode for the doctor. Of course I was pouring rain. That is practically the only help I had.
14. If you used oxen, how many did you have?

When and where did you obtain them?

In regard to oxen and farming, Mr. Bennett mentioned that he had oxen in 1909 in Alabama.

He was born in England but came to America in 1870. He farmed in Alabama for many years until 1911 when he moved to Texas.

He was married twice, first to Jane Smith and then to Mary Johnson.

He had two children, John and Mary.

He died in 1920 at the age of 65.

He was a member of the Baptist Church and attended services regularly.

He enjoyed hunting and fishing in his spare time.

He was a hard worker and provided for his family well.

He left behind a legacy of hard work and dedication.

May God bless him and his family.

When and where did you obtain them?

1909 in Roulcan

Did you have any memorable experiences with them?

If they liked too much they would ride for the most part, but nothing could stop them. - or developed an habit to haul if necessary over ice by kneeling and pulling on their knees.

18.

16. With what machinery did you start farming?

Walking plows, discs and a drill.

17. What was the first tractor you used and when?

Massey Harris Twin Coders

Was it used for belt power or for field power?

Field power

If this was not the first tractor in your district, do you remember the first? Give details.

Fresh Belleflor purchased and bought in a clean state and plowing ad September 1910.

18. To what extent did other members of the family assist in farming operations?

None - my father for the first year in building etc he also opened a store and my mother only stayed on the land in winter to cultivate potatoes.

What was the first hired help you had?

None

Answered on separate page.

To what extent did you make use of hired help during your farming career?

None except in extra years for harvesting.

25. What weeds were present in your district when you first arrived and which were most common?

Practically, the only early weed was "Frend weed."

26. What new varieties of weeds appeared after you settled? (Give date of appearance if possible).

Wild oats .. 1930

27. What method of harvesting and threshing grain did you first use? Binders and separators - in 1910, the Butter - Esselton had a horse power separator and threshed my crop late. I also operated a second binder. I threshed my crop with steam outfits.

How many men were required in these operations?

Steamer: 17 men.

28. When did you first market grain, livestock, or other produce from your farm?

Livestock: Early in our history in Willow Bunch.
Grain: In 1918, when the hayfields reached Vermilion.

How did you haul grain to market?

Team.

Was most of your grain hauled in the fall, or did you do winter hauling with team and sleigh?

Farm, in fall to Vermilion, but not in winter with sleighs to Vermilion across the lake, distance Vermilion 22 miles, Vermilion across the lake 15 miles.

To what point?

How far?

What prices did you receive?

$65.72 cents a bushel.

In what year was the first grain elevator constructed in your district? 1927-28.

By what company?

Wheat Pool Federal.

I am using the word "Pool" instead of "Pool" I still had to Willow Bunch, which was served by a railroad in 1927.
